revision.text: ==English== [[File:Southern Three Banded Armadillo 001-2.jpg|right|thumb|A southern three-banded armadillo (''Tolypeutes matacus''), a xenarthran]] {{wikipedia|Xenarthra}} ===Etymology=== From {{uder|en|grc|ξένος||strange}} + {{m|grc|ἄρθρον||joint}}. ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|zoology}} Any mammal of the of superorder [[Xenarthra]], of the Americas; an [[anteater]], [[armadillo]] or [[sloth]]. #* '''1978''', Terry A. Vaughan, James M. Ryan, Nicholas J. Czaplewski, ''Mammalogy'', [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=96HuAAAAMAAJ&q=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&dq=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=12VQVan6EMLBmAXtzIHYDg&ved=0CKgDEOgBMEw page 355], #*: Elephant-shrews, '''xenarthrans''', hystricognathous rodents, cetaceans, some pinnipeds, and primates depart sharply from this trend, however. #* '''2000''', John F. Eisenberg, Kent H. Redford, ''Mammals of the Neotropics'', Volume 3: Ecuador, Bolivia, Brazil, [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=p2MDAzCeQQoC&pg=PA90&dq=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=12VQVan6EMLBmAXtzIHYDg&ved=0CHkQ6AEwEw#v=onepage&q=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&f=false page 90], #*: '''Xenarthrans''' appear to have originated in South America and to have undergone their major adaptive radiation there (Reig 1981). #* '''2008''', Christine Argot, ''3: Changing Views in Paleontology: The Story of a Giant (Megatherium, Xenarthra)'', Eric J. Sargis, Marian Dagosto (editors), ''Mammalian Evolutionary Morphology: A Tribute to Frederick S. Szalay'', [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=6_n2Sr7kIO8C&pg=PA37&dq=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=12VQVan6EMLBmAXtzIHYDg&ved=0CIACEOgBMCs#v=onepage&q=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&f=false page 37], #*: Only four '''xenarthran''' families are extant today, providing little indication of the past richness of the order. #* '''2010''', Ana Maria Jansen, André Luiz Rodrigues Roque, ''11: Domestic and Wild Mammalian Reservoirs'', Jenny Telleria, Michel Tibayrenc, ''American Trypanosomiasis: Chagas Disease: One Hundred Years of Research'', [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=sXL_ESJ_Zl4C&pg=PA249&dq=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=12VQVan6EMLBmAXtzIHYDg&ved=0CIABEOgBMBQ#v=onepage&q=%22xenarthran%22%7C%22xenarthrans%22&f=false page 249], #*: Marsupials and '''xenarthrans''', which represented the autochthonous mammalian fauna, were ''T.<sup>[Trypanosoma]</sup> cruzi''’s first hosts. ====Usage notes==== The '''xenarthrans''' were previously included within now obsolete ([[polyphyletic]]) order [[Edentata]], along with [[aardvark]]s and [[pangolin]]s. ====Hypernyms==== * {{sense|any species of Xenarthra}} {{l|en|edentate}} {{qualifier|obsolete classification}} ====Hyponyms==== * {{sense|any species of Xenarthra}} {{l|en|anteater}}, {{l|en|armadillo}}, {{l|en|glyptodont}}, [[pampathere]], [[sloth]] ====Derived terms==== * [[xenarthrous]] ====Translations==== {{trans-top|mammal}} * French: {{t+|fr|xénarthre|m}} {{trans-mid}} * Italian: {{t+|it|xenartro|m}} * Polish: {{t|pl|szczerbak|m}} {{trans-bottom}} [[Category:en:Mammals]]
